revision.text:
'''Asian handicap''' betting is a form of betting on [[association football|football]] in which teams are handicapped according to their form, so that a stronger team must win by more goals for a punter betting on them to win. The system originated in Indonesia and has gained popularity in the early 21st century. It is a form of [[spread betting]]. Handicaps typically range from one-quarter goal to several goals, in increments of half- or even quarter-goals.<ref>[http://www.scmp.com/magazines/post-magazine/article/1211405/games-without-frontiers Games without frontiers], SCMP Post Magazine[http://sbo88live.com], David Eimer, 14 Apr 2013</ref>
Most importantly, Asian handicap betting reduces the possible number of outcomes from three (in traditional 1X2 wagering) to two by eliminating the draw outcome.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.topbettingreviews.com/arbitrage-betting-asian-handicap/ | title=An Introduction to Arbitrage Betting and the Asian Handicap | publisher=TBR | date=25 January 2014 | accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref> This simplification delivers two betting options that each have a near 50% chance of success.
Asian handicaps are both good and bad for [[bookmakers]]. On one hand, they help bookmakers minimize risk by facilitating trading with parity or balancing the amount of wagering on each side of the match. This enables bookmakers to take larger positions on major matches. On the other hand, Asian handicap markets are typically low margin offerings that do not contribute as significantly to the gross win as higher [[vigorish]] betting options like 1X2.<ref>{{cite web | last = Charles | first = Gillespie | publisher = WSN | date = 2007-12-04 | url = http://www.wsn.com/2007/12/04/football/editorial/football-betting/asian-handicap-betting-basics_324721/ | accessdate = 2009-04-02 | title = Asian Handicap Betting Basics| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090303234028/http://www.wsn.com/2007/12/04/football/editorial/football-betting/asian-handicap-betting-basics_324721/| archivedate= 3 March 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The term "Asian handicap" was coined by journalist Joe Saumarez Smith in November 1998. He was asked by an Indonesian bookmaker, Joe Phan, to provide a translation of the betting method that was termed 'hang cheng betting' by bookmakers in Asia.<ref>{{cite web | last = George | first = Haggett | publisher = BetAsia | date = 2002-05-14 | url = http://www.betasia.com/features/how-to-win/general/5874/origin-of-asian-handicap.html | accessdate = 2009-10-20 | title = Origin of Asian Handicap| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091031041314/http://www.betasia.com/features/how-to-win/general/5874/origin-of-asian-handicap.html| archivedate= 31 October 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Description== [[Football (soccer)]]<ref>{{ cite web|url= http://www.unogoallive.com/ |title=UnoGoal Livescore Terbaru Real Time Match Soccer Results|accessdate= 26 December 2017}}</ref> is one of the few sports in the world where a draw is a fairly common outcome. With traditional fixed odds, draws are treated as an additional outcome to the game. In other words, bettors lose when they place a wager on either team to win and the game draws. With Asian handicaps, however, the chance for a draw is eliminated by use of a handicap that forces a winner. This creates a situation where each team has a 50-50 chance of winning; similar to the odds for a basketball or football spread handicap typically offered by Las Vegas sportsbooks.
Asian handicap is a form of betting that creates a more level betting environment between two mismatched competing teams by giving a "handicap" (expressed in goals or points) to the teams before kick-off. In Asian handicap, a goal deficit is given to the team more likely to win (i.e. the Favourite) and a head start is given to the team less favoured to win (i.e. the Underdog).
This system works in a straightforward manner. The [[bookmaker]]'s aim is to create a handicap or "line" that will make the chance of either team winning (considering the handicap) as close to 50% as possible. Since the odds are as close to 50% as possible, [[bookmakers]] offer payouts close to [[even money]], or 1.90 to 2.00. Asian handicaps start at a quarter goal and can go as high as 2.5 or 3 goals in matches with a huge disparity in ability. What makes Asian handicaps most interesting is the use of quarter goals to get the "line" as close as possible. Taken in conjunction with the posted total for the game, the handicap essentially predicts the game's final score.
==Quarter-goal or two-way handicaps== Subsequently, many matches are handicapped in ½ and ¼ intervals; both of which eliminate the possibility of a push since no one can score a half-goal. Quarter (¼) handicaps split the bet between the two closest ½ intervals. For instance, a $1000 bet with a handicap of 1¾ is the same as betting $500 at 1½ and $500 at 2. With ¼ handicap bets, you can win and draw (win ½ of wager) or lose and draw (lose ½ wager). The ¼-goal handicap may be expressed by some bookmakers as "0 and ½", or as "pk and ½" (for "pick-em") - especially for bookmakers whose systems are designed for sports like [[American football]] and [[basketball]], where bets have a handicap that is designed to make the odds as close to even as possible.
The bettor's stake is automatically divided equally and placed as 2 separate bets. This means that with a handicap point of 0-0.5 or 0 and ½, half of your stake is on the 0 point handicap and the other half is on the 0.5 handicap.
Match: Everton vs. Newcastle United
Handicap: Newcastle +1.0, +1.5
Explained: This handicap states that half of your bet goes on Newcastle to win, draw, or lose by less than 1 goal; and half on Newcastle to win, draw, or lose by less than 1.5 goals.
If the final score is Everton 1-0 Newcastle, half your bet would be refunded due to draw (Everton 1 - +1 Newcastle, i.e: Newcastle lost by exactly one goal). The second half would win (Everton 1 - +1.5 Newcastle, i.e: Newcastle lost by less than 1.5 goals).
==Whole handicaps and draws== In the event that a whole number is used for the handicap, the handicap adjusted final score could result in a draw. This situation is not a draw, but a push. With a push, all bettors have their original wagers returned as there is no winner. The plus signs in the Team result columns indicate "or more", eg. "2+" means "by 2 goals or more".
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Handicap || Team result || Bet result || Handicap || Team result || Bet result |- ! rowspan="3" | 0 | Win || Win ! rowspan="3" | 0 | Win || Win |- | Draw || Stake refund || Draw || Stake refund |- | Lose || Lose || Lose || Lose |- ! rowspan="3" | - 0.25 | Win || Win ! rowspan="3" | + 0.25 | Win || Win |- | Draw || Half lose || Draw || Half win |- | Lose || Lose || Lose || Lose |- ! rowspan="3" | - 0.50 | Win || Win ! rowspan="3" | + 0.50 | Win || Win |- | Draw || Lose || Draw || Win |- | Lose || Lose || Lose || Lose |- ! rowspan="4" | - 0.75 | Win by 2+ || Win ! rowspan="4" | + 0.75 | Win || Win |- | Win by 1 || Half win || Draw || Win |- | Draw || Lose || Lose by 1 || Half Lose |- | Lose || Lose || Lose by 2+ || Lose |- ! rowspan="4" | - 1.00 | Win by 2+ || Win ! rowspan="4" | + 1.00 | Win || Win |- | Win by 1 || Stake refund || Draw || Win |- | Draw || Lose || Lose by 1 || Stake refund |- | Lose || Lose || Lose by 2+ || Lose |- ! rowspan="4" | - 1.25 | Win by 2+ || Win ! rowspan="4" | + 1.25 | Win || Win |- | Win by 1 || Half lose || Draw || Win |- | Draw || Lose || Lose by 1 || Half win |- | Lose || Lose || Lose by 2+ || Lose |- ! rowspan="4" | - 1.50 | Win by 2+ || Win ! rowspan="4" | + 1.50 | Win || Win |- | Win by 1 || Lose || Draw || Win |- | Draw || Lose || Lose by 1 || Win |- | Lose || Lose || Lose by 2+ || Lose |- ! rowspan="5" | - 1.75 | Win by 3+ || Win ! rowspan="5" | + 1.75 | Win || Win |- | Win by 2 || Half win || Draw || Win |- | Win by 1 || Lose || Lose by 1 || Win |- | Draw || Lose || Lose by 2 || Half lose |- | Lose || Lose || Lose by 3+ || Lose |- ! rowspan="5" | - 2.00 | Win by 3+ || Win ! rowspan="5" | + 2.00 | Win || Win |- | Win by 2 || Stake refund || Draw || Win |- | Win by 1 || Lose || Lose by 1 || Win |- | Draw || Lose || Lose by 2 || Stake refund |- | Lose || Lose || Lose by 3+ || Lose |}

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Baltic languages}} {{Multiple issues| {{original research|date=July 2013}} {{refimprove|date=July 2013}} }} {{Infobox language |name = Balti |nativename = {{nq|بلتی}}
{{bo-textonly|སྦལ་འཐུས་}} |states = [[Baltistan]], [[Kashmir]], [[Ladakh]], and small pockets in [[Karachi]], [[Rawalpindi]] |region = [[Pakistan]], [[India]] |ethnicity = [[Balti people]] |speakers = 290,000 |date = 1992–2001 |ref = e18 |familycolor = Sino-Tibetan |fam2 = [[Tibeto-Kanauri languages|Tibeto-Kanauri]]? |fam3 = [[Bodish languages|Bodish]] |fam4 = [[Tibetic languages|Tibetic]] |fam5 = [[Ladakhi–Balti languages|Ladakhi–Balti]] |script = [[Perso-Arabic script]] and [[Tibetan alphabet]] |iso3 = bft |glotto = balt1258 |glottorefname = Balti |image = Balti in nastaliq.jpg }} '''Balti''' ({{bo|t=སྦལ་ཏི།}}, {{bo|w=bal ti skad}}; [[Nastaʿlīq script]]: {{nq|بلتی}}) is a [[Tibetic languages|Tibetic language]] spoken in the [[Baltistan]] region of [[Gilgit-Baltistan]], [[Pakistan]], the [[Nubra Valley]] of [[Leh district]], and in the [[Kargil district]] of [[Jammu and Kashmir]], [[India]].{{cite book|title=Census of India, 1961: Jammu and Kashmir|accessdate=18 August 2017|year=1961|publisher=[[Registrar General and Census Commissioner of India]]|language=English|page=357}} It is quite different from [[Standard Tibetan]]. Many sounds of [[Old Tibetan]] that were lost in Standard Tibetan are retained in the Balti language. It also has a simple [[pitch accent]] system only in multi-syllabic words{{cite journal|last1=Sprigg|first1=R. K.|title=Lepcha and Balti Tibetan: Tonal or Non-Tonal Languages?|journal=Asia Major|date=1966|volume=12|pages=185–201|ref=harv}} while Standard Tibetan has a complex and distinct pitch system that includes [[tone contour]]. == Ethnography == All people living in [[Baltistan]] may be referred to as ''Balti''. The [[Greeks]] derived ''Byaltae'' from {{bo|t=སྦལ་ཏིའི་|w=sbal-ti}}, which, in Tibetan, means "water gorge." The historian [[Ptolemy (general)|Ptolemy]], also a general in the army of [[Alexander the Great]], named the region "Byaltae" in his book.{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} In fact, [[Baltistan]] is the [[Persian language|Persian]] translation of ''Baltiyul'', "homeland of Balti." [[Balti people]] are settled on both banks of the [[Indus River]] from [[Kargil district]] in the east to [[Haramosh Peak]] in the west and from the [[Karakoram]] in the north to [[Deosai National Park]] in the south. The Balti ethnicity is primarily [[Tibetan people|Tibetan]] in origin, with some [[Dardic people|Dardic]] admixture. Balti is a Tibetic language. In some rural areas, the [[Shina people]] still speak the [[Shina language]] but they are very few in number. Also, their language has many loan words from Balti, as Balti is the majority language in Baltistan . To develop Balti, local intellectuals like [[Yusuf Hussain Abadi]] have worked on the language, rediscovering the history and reviving the Tibetan script in Baltistan after six centuries (1980). He wrote the book 'Balti Zabaan' in 1990, the first book on the language. Abadi translated the Quran into Balti in 1995. Later on, many people inspired by him worked on Balti. [[Ghulam Hassan Lobsang]] wrote a book 'Balti Grammar' in both English and Urdu versions: "Balti Grammar" and "Balti English Grammar". The latter was published by Bern University Switzerland in 1995. The Balti have a reputation for being very forbearing, cheerful and hospitable people. During the [[Maqpon dynasty]] (from the twelfth century to 1840), the Balti invaded [[Ladakh]] and [[Tibet]] in the east and [[Gilgit]] and [[Chitral (princely state)|Chitral]] many times, thus making these people acknowledge the martial abilities of the Balti. The modern population of Baltistan is a heterogeneous mixture of ethnic groups. Tibetans form the principal ethnic group in the area accounting for 75 percent of the population. Outside Baltistan, there are several Balti communities located in Pakistan's urban and rural areas. ==Classification== Tournadre (2005)*N. Tournadre (2005) "L'aire linguistique tibétaine et ses divers dialectes." ''Lalies'', 2005, n°25, p. 7–56 [http://tournadre.nicolas.free.fr/fichiers/2005-aire.pdf] considers Balti, [[Ladakhi language|Ladakhi]], and [[Purgi language|Purgi]] to be distinct languages because they do not have [[mutual intelligibility]]. As a group, they are termed Ladakhi–Balti or Western Archaic Tibetan, as opposed to Western Innovative Tibetan languages, such as [[Lahuli–Spiti language|Lahuli–Spiti]]. [[File:Balti language speaking areas.png|thumb|Geographical distribution of Balti language speaking area (including Purigi dialect, sometimes considered as different from Balti language)]] The missionary, orientalist and linguist [[Heinrich August Jäschke]] (1817–1883) classified Balti as one of the westernmost [[Tibetic languages]]. In his ''Tibetan–English Dictionary'', he defines it as "Bal (Balti), the most westerly of the districts in which the Tibetan language is spoken".{{cite book|ref=harv|last=Heinrich|first=Heinrich August|authorlink=Heinrich August Jäschke|title=A Tibetan-English Dictionary, with Special Reference to the Prevailing Dialects: To which is Added an English-Tibetan Vocabulary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_RQTAAAAYAAJ|year=1881|publisher=Unger Brothers (T. Grimm)}} == Script == The predominant writing system currently in use for Balti is the Perso-Arabic script, although there have been attempts to revive the Tibetan script, which was used between the 8th and the 16th centuries.{{sfn|Bashir|2016|pp=808–09}}. Additionally, there are two, nowadays possibly extinct, indigenous writing systems,{{sfn|Pandey|2010}} and there have been proposals for the adoption of [[Roman script|Roman]]–{{sfn|Bashir|2016|p=808}} as well as [[Devanagari]]-based orthographies.{{sfn|Pandey|2010|p=1}} The main script for writing Balti is the local adaptation of the [[Tibetan alphabet]] which is called yige in baltiyul [[baltistan]], but it is often written in the [[Persian alphabet]], especially within Pakistan. In 1985, Abadi added four new letters to the Tibetan script and seven new letters to the [[Persian script]] to adapt both of them according to the need of Balti language. Two of the four added letters now stand included in the Tibetan Unicode alphabet. The Tibetan script had been in vogue in Baltistan until the last quarter of the 14th century, when the Baltis converted to Islam. Since then, Persian script replaced the Tibetan script, but the former had no letters for seven Balti sounds and was in vogue in spite of the fact that it was defective. Adding the seven new letters has now made it a complete script for Balti. Recently, a number of Balti scholars and social activists have attempted to promote the use of the Tibetan Balti or "Yige" alphabet with the aim of helping to preserve indigenous Balti and Ladakhi culture and ethnic identity. Following a request from this community, the September 2006 Tokyo meeting of ISO/IEC 10646 WG2 agreed to encode two characters which are invented by Abadi (U+0F6B TIBETAN LETTER KKA and TIBETAN U+0F6C LETTER RRA) in the [[Universal Coded Character Set|ISO 10646]] and [[Unicode]] standards in order to support rendering Urdu loanwords present in modern Balti using the Yige alphabet. == Areas == Now, Balti is spoken in the whole of Baltistan in the northern Pakistan and some parts of Northern India in Jammu and Kashmir. It is said that Purki-dialect of [[Purgi language|Purgi]] and Suru-Kartse valleys come into the Balti group linguistically to some extent. However, Balti is spoken by people living in Baltistan (Pakistan), different parts of the states of northern India like Dehradun, Masoorie, Kalsigate, Chakrotta, Ambadi in Uttrakhand and parts of Jammu and Kashmir like Jammu and Ramban in Jammu region, Hariparbat, Dalgate and Tral in Kashmir region. In the twin districts of Ladakh region (Kargil & Leh) it is spoken in Kargil city and its surrounding villages like Hardass, Lato, Karkitchhoo and Balti Bazar, and in Leh- Turtuk, Bogdang, Tyakshi including Leh city and nearby villages. == Evolution == Since Pakistan gained control of the region in 1948, Urdu words have been introduced into local dialects and languages, including Balti. In modern times, Balti has no native names or vocabulary for dozens of newly invented and introduced things; instead, Urdu and English words are being used in Balti. Balti has retained many honorific words that are characteristic of Tibetan dialects and many other languages. The first Balti grammar was written in Urdu by Ghulam Hassan Lobsang. Below are a few examples: {|class="wikitable" |- !Ordinary Balti !Text Writing!! Honorific !! Ladakhi !!Meaning |- |Ata |اتا|| Baba || Aba || Father |- |kho |کھو|| kho || - || he |- |gashay |گشے|| liakhmo || liakhmo || Beautiful |- |paynay |پینے|| khumul || painay || Money |- |bila |بلا|| Bila || bilo || Cat |- |su |سُو|| su || sou || Who |- |Ano/Amo |انو/امو|| Zizi || Ama || Mother |- |Kaka |ککا|| Kacho || Acho || Brother (elder) |- |Bustring |بُسترنگ|| Zung || Nama || Woman / Wife |- |Momo |مومو|| Jangmocho || Ajang || Maternal uncle |- |Nene |نےنے|| Nenecho || Ane || Aunt |- |Bu |بُو|| Bucho || Tugu || Son |- |Fru |فُرو|| Nono || Busa || Boy |- |Apo |اپو|| Apocho || Meme || Grandfather |- |Api |اپی|| Apicho || Abi || Grandmother |- |Ashe |اشے|| Ashcho || Singmo || Sister (elder) |- |Zo |زو|| bjes || Zo || Eat |- |Thung |تُھونگ|| bjes || Thung || Drink |- |Ong |اونگ|| Shokhs || Yong || Come |- |Song |سونگ|| Shokhs || Song || Go |- |Zair |زیر|| Kasal-byung || Zer || Speak/Say |- |Ngid tong |نِت تونگ|| gزim tong || Ngid tong || Sleep (go to) |- |Lagpa |لقپا|| Phyaq-laq/g || Lagpa || Hand/Arm |- |Khyang |کھیانگ|| Yang/Yari-phyaqpo || Khyorang || You |- |Kangma |کنگما|| gzok-po || kang || Leg |} == Literature == No prose literature except proverb collections have been found written in Balti. Some epics and sagas appear in oral literature such as the ''[[Epic of King Gesar]]'', and the stories of ''rgya lu cho lo bzang'' and ''rgya lu sras bu''. All other literature is in verse. Balti literature has adopted numerous [[Persian language|Persian]] styles of verse and vocables which amplify the beauty and melody of its poetry. Nearly all the languages and dialects of the mountain region in the north of Pakistan such as [[Pashto]], [[Khowar language|Khowar]] and Shina are [[Indo-Aryan languages|Indo-Aryan]] or [[Iranian languages|Iranic]] languages, but Balti is one of the [[Sino-Tibetan languages]]. As such, it has nothing in common with neighboring languages except some loanwords absorbed as a result of linguistic contact. Balti and [[Ladakhi language|Ladakhi]] are closely related. The major issue facing the development of Balti literature is its centuries-long isolation from [[Tibet]], owing to political divisions and strong religious differences and even from its immediate neighbor Ladakh for the last 50 years. Separated from its linguistic kin, Balti is under pressure from more dominant languages such as [[Urdu]]. This is compounded by the lack of a suitable means of transcribing the language following the abandonment of its original Tibetan script. The Baltis do not have the awareness to revive their original script and there is no institution that could restore it and persuade the people to use it again. Even if the script is revived, it would need modification to express certain Urdu phonemes that occur in common loanwords within Balti. Examples of poetry: {{quote|
تھونما زینب قتلگاہ عباس چھوزورکھا سھوکفامید
تھون نارے ستریمو لا تعزیم چی بیک پارگولا نین مہ مید
}} {{quote|
:Youq fangsay thalang paqzi na mandoq na mabour na :Na drolbi laming yani si soq fangse chi thobtook :Nasir Karmi
}} ==See also== * [[Sart]] * [[Balti people]] * [[Gilgit-Baltistan]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * *{{Cite book| last = Bashir| first = Elena L.| date = 2016| chapter = Perso-Arabic adaptions for South Asian languages| editor-last1 = Hock| editor-first1 = Hans Henrich| editor-last2 = Bashir| editor-first2 = Elena L.| title = The languages and linguistics of South Asia: a comprehensive guide| series = World of Linguistics| publisher = De Gruyter Mouton| location = Berlin| isbn = 978-3-11-042715-8| pages = 803–9| ref = harv}} *{{Cite report|last = Pandey| first = Anshuman| date = 2010| title = Introducing Another Script for Writing Balti| url = https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2010/10231-n3842-balti.pdf| ref = harv}} * Muhammad Yousuf Hussainabadi, 'Baltistan per aik Nazar'. 1984. * Hussainabadi, Mohamad Yusuf. ''Balti Zaban''. 1990. * Muhammad Hassan Hasrat, 'Tareekh-e-Adbiat;. * Muhammad Yousuf Hussainabadi, 'Tareekh-e-Baltistan'. 2003. * Engineer Wazir Qalbi Ali, 'Qadam Qadam Baltistan'. 2006. * "A Short Sketch of Balti English Grammar" by [[Ghulam Hassan Lobsang]], 1995. * Everson, Michael. [http://std.dkuug.dk/jtc1/sc2/wg2/docs/n2985.pdf ISO/IEC JTC1/SC2/WG2 N2985: Proposal to add four Tibetan characters for Balti to the BMP of the UCS]. 2005-09-05 * Read, A.F.C. ''Balti grammar''.London:The Royal Asiatic society, 1934. * Sprigg, Richard Keith. ''Balti-English English-Balti dictionary''. Richmond: RoutledgeCurzon, 2002. * Backstrom, Peter C. ''Languages of Northern Areas (Sociolinguistic Survey of Northern Pakistan, 2)'', 1992. 417 pp. {{ISBN|969-8023-12-7}}. == External links == {{Incubator|code=bft}} * [https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr3-2 Unicode] * [http://koshur.org/Linguistic/7.html Koshur: The Balti Language] * [http://www.tibet.com/newsroom/tibetan%20script.htm Tibetan script makes a comeback in Pakistan] * [http://std.dkuug.dk/jtc1/sc2/wg2/docs/n2985.pdf Proposal to add four Tibetan characters for Balti to the BMP of the UCS] * [[Andrew West (linguist)|Andrew West]], [http://babelstone.blogspot.com/2006/08/tibetan-extensions-2-balti.html Tibetan Extensions 2 : Balti] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/1491179.stm Pakistan's Northern Areas dilemma] * [http://www.northernareas.org.pk Northern Areas Development Gateway] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040107222554/http://paknews.com/articles.php?id=1&date1=2003-04-17 Pakistan's Northern Areas] * [http://wikimapia.org/#lat=35.3029642&lon=75.6247973&z=18&l=0&m=a&v=2] * [[Wikibooks:Research on Tibetan Languages: A Bibliography|A Bibliography of Tibetan Linguistics]] * [https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.121696557911269.30420.120793871334871&type=3&l=79831095a2] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K5W1SDLHcpA] {{Bodic languages}} {{Languages of Pakistan}} {{Languages of India}} [[Category:Bodic languages]] [[Category:Languages of Gilgit-Baltistan]] [[Category:Languages of Jammu and Kashmir]] [[Category:Baltistan]] [[Category:Languages written in Tibetan script]] [[Category:Arabic alphabets for South Asian languages]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|text=the [[Bangi language]] of central Africa}} {{Infobox language |name=Bangime |nativename=''Baŋgɛri-mɛ'' |region=Dogon cliffs, [[Mali]] |speakers=2,000 |date=2005 |ref=e18 |familycolor=isolate |family=[[Language isolate]] |iso3=dba |map=Map of the Dogon languages.svg |mapcaption={{legend|#ff6969|Bangi-me, among the Dogon languages}} |glotto=bang1363 |glottorefname=Bangime }}
'''Bangime''' {{IPAc-en|ˌ|b|æ|ŋ|ɡ|i|ˈ|m|eɪ}} (''bàŋɡí–mɛ̀'', or, in full, ''Bàŋgɛ́rí-mɛ̀''<ref>/Vr/ sequences are frequently dropped. The language has also been called ''Numadaw'', which is part of a greeting.</ref>) is a [[language isolate]] spoken by 1,500 ethnic [[Dogon people|Dogon]] in seven villages in southern [[Mali]], who call themselves the ''bàŋɡá–ndɛ̀'' ("hidden people"). Long known to be highly divergent from (other) [[Dogon languages]], it was first proposed as a possible isolate by [[Roger Blench|Blench]] (2005). Research since then has confirmed that it appears to be unrelated to neighbouring languages.
Roger Blench, who discovered the language was not a [[Dogon languages|Dogon language]], notes, :''This language contains some Niger–Congo roots but is lexically very remote from all other languages in West Africa. It is presumably the last remaining representative of the languages spoken prior to the expansion of the Dogon proper,'' which he dates to 3,000–4,000 years ago.
Bangime has been characterised as an [[anti-language]], i.e., a language that serves to prevent its speakers from being understood by outsiders, possibly associated with the Bangande villages having been a refuge for escapees from slave [[Caravan (travellers)|caravans]].<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/S0262-4079(14)61070-8| volume = 222| issue = 2971| pages = 42–45| last = Bradley| first = Matthew Timothy| title = The 'secret ones': tales from Mali's anti-language| journal = New Scientist| date = 2014-05-31| url = https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22229710.700-people-of-secrets-the-slave-sanctuary-antilanguage.html}}</ref>
Blench (2015) suggests that Bangime and Dogon languages may have a substratum from a "missing" branch of [[Nilo-Saharan]] that had split off relatively early from [[Proto-Nilo-Saharan]], and tentatively calls that branch "Plateau".<ref>Blench, Roger. 2015. [https://www.academia.edu/15754234/Was_there_a_now-vanished_branch_of_Nilo-Saharan_on_the_Dogon_Plateau_Evidence_from_substrate_vocabulary_in_Bangime_and_Dogon Was there a now-vanished branch of Nilo-Saharan on the Dogon Plateau? Evidence from substrate vocabulary in Bangime and Dogon].</ref>
==Locations== Bangime is spoken in 7 villages east of Karge, near [[Bandiagara]], [[Mopti Region]], central [[Mali]] (Blench 2007). The villages are: *Bara ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: {{IPA|[bara]}}) *Bounou ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: {{IPA|[bunu]}}) *Niana ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: {{IPA|[ɲana]}}) *Die'ni ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: {{IPA|[jene]}}) *Digari ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: {{IPA|[diɡarɔ]}}) *Doro ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: {{IPA|[dɔrɔ]}}) *Due ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: {{IPA|[ʔjeni]}})
==Morphology== Bangime is an [[isolating language]]. The only productive affixes are the plural and a [[diminutive]], which are seen in the words for the people and language above.
==Phonology==
=== Vowels === Vowels have an [[Advanced and retracted tongue root|±ATR]] distinction, which affects neighbouring consonants, but unusually for such systems, there is no ATR [[vowel harmony]] in Bangime. Vowels may be long or [[Nasalised vowel|nasalised]].
{| class="wikitable" |+ ! !Front !Central !Back |- !Close |i | |u |- !Close-mid |e | |o |- !Open-mid |ɛ | |ɔ |- !Open | |a | |}
=== Consonants === Bangime has consonant distinctions not found in the Dogon languages.[https://s3.amazonaws.com/academia.edu.documents/42030562/African_linguistic_isolates.pdf?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAIWOWYYGZ2Y53UL3A&Expires=1526872805&Signature=QykLYKQ%2BZ0SaMXcREtVAyBJD0rI%3D&response-content-disposition=inline%3B%20filename%3DAfrican_language_isolates.pdf] {|class="wikitable IPA" ! colspan="2" rowspan="2" | ! colspan="2" |Bilabial ! colspan="2" |Alveolar ! rowspan="2" |Alveolo-palatal ! colspan="2" |Palatal ! colspan="3" |Velar ! rowspan="2" |Glottal |- !{{Small|plain}} !{{Small|prenasalized}} !{{Small|plain}} !{{Small|prenasalized}} !{{Small|plain}} !{{Small|labialized}} !{{Small|plain}} !{{Small|prenasalized}} !{{Small|labialized}} |- ! rowspan="2" |Stop !{{Small|voiceless}} |p |ᵐp||t |ⁿt ||| |||k |ᵑk | | |- !{{Small|voiced}} |b |ᵐb||d |ⁿd ||| |||ɡ |ᵑg | | |- ! colspan="2" |Fricative | | ||s | |ɕ||ʒ ||| | | |h |- ! colspan="2" |Nasal |m | |n | | |ɲ | |ŋ | | | |- ! colspan="2" |Approximant | | ||l | |||j |ɥ|| | |w | |- ! colspan="2" |Trill | | |r | | | | | | | | |}
NC sequences tend to drop the plosive, and often [[lenition|lenite]] to a nasalized sonorant: {{IPA|[búndà] ~ [búr̃a] ~ [bún]}} 'finish', {{IPA|[támbà] ~ [táw̃à] ~ [támà]}} 'chew'.
{{IPA|/b/}} and {{IPA|/ɡ/}} appear as {{IPA|[ʋ]}} and {{IPA|[ɣ]}}, depending on the ATR status of the adjacent vowels.
{{IPA|/s/}} appears as {{IPA|[ʃ]}} before non-low vowels, {{IPA|/t/}} and {{IPA|/j/}} as {{IPA|[tʃ]}} and {{IPA|[ʒ]}} before either of the high front vowels. {{IPA|/j/}} is realized as {{IPA|[dʒ]}} after a nasal.
=== Tone === There are three tones on [[mora (linguistics)|mora]]s (short syllables): high, low and rising. In addition, falling tone may occur on long (bimoraic) syllables. Syllables may also have no inherent tone.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Blench, Robert, Bangime description and word list [http://www.rogerblench.info/Language/Isolates/Bangime%20wordlist%20paper.pdf (2005)][http://www.rogerblench.info/Language/Isolates/Bangi%20me%20%20paper%20for%20MT.pdf (2007)] * Hantgan & Vydrin, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120316221245/http://25images.ish-lyon.cnrs.fr/player/player.php?id=72&id_sequence=426&quality=hd "Bangime, Justification as a Language Isolate"], presented at the Language Isolates in Africa workshop, Lyons, December 4, 2010 * Hantgan, Abbie, [https://edmond.mpdl.mpg.de/imeji/file/_cwcyJ2vd8oGGVTd/ba/ee/85/93-e8b3-4caf-bc65-ee41f3e2dba2/0/original/34f3a90483c513e55845c2e4cab18c9c.pdf ''A Grammar of Bangime''] (draft, 2010) * {{cite thesis |last= Hantgan |first= Abbie |author= |date= July 2013 |title= Aspects of Bangime phonology, morphology, and morphosyntax |degree= Ph.D. |publisher= Indiana University |docket= |oclc= 893980514 |url= http://hdl.handle.net/2022/18024}}
==External links== *[http://dogonlanguages.org/bangime.cfm Bangime] at the Dogon languages and Bangime project

revision.text:
{{Infobox philosopher | region = [[Western philosophy]] | era = [[Contemporary philosophy]] | image = Berit_Brogaard.jpg | caption = | name = Berit Oskar Brogaard | birth_place = [[Copenhagen]] | birth_date = {{b-da|28 August 1970}} | school_tradition = [[Analytic philosophy|Analytic]] | main_interests = [[Philosophy of mind]]
[[Cognitive neuroscience]]
[[Philosophy of language]] | notable_ideas = [[Synesthesia]] as a gateway to hidden areas of the brain; left-brain activation during [[visual memory]]; perceptual reports; primitive [[color]] properties; dynamic [[two-dimensional semantics]] | influences = [[David Chalmers]], [[Barry Smith (academic)]] }} '''Berit Oskar Brogaard''' (born August 28, 1970) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] and [[United States|American]] [[philosopher]] specializing in the areas of [[cognitive neuroscience]], [[philosophy of mind]], and [[philosophy of language]]. Her recent work concerns [[synesthesia]], [[savant syndrome]], [[blindsight]] and perceptual reports. She is Professor of Philosophy and runs a perception lab at the [[University of Miami]] in Coral Gables, Florida.{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/brogaardb/cv|title=cv - BeritBrogaard|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://brogaardlab.com|title=Brogaard Lab for Multisensory Research - Synesthesia - Savant Syndrome - Autism|work=Brogaard Lab for Multisensory Research}} She is also co-editor of the influential [[Philosophical Gourmet Report]]. == Education and career == Brogaard was born and raised in Copenhagen. From an early age, she excelled at physics, mathematics, and biology, eventually completing her undergraduate education at the [[University of Copenhagen]] with a bachelor's degree in linguistics and philosophy. She then studied [[neuroscience]] under the direction of Thue Schwartz, [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]], D.M.Sci. at University of Copenhagen and the Danish National Hospital.{{cite web|url=http://www.newappsblog.com/2011/11/new-apps-interview-berit-brogaard.html|title=New APPS Interview: Berit Brogaard|work=New APPS: Art, Politics, Philosophy, Science}} Upon completion of her degrees in Copenhagen she studied linguistics and philosophy at [[University at Buffalo, The State University of New York|the University at Buffalo]], where she obtained her [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] with [[Barry Smith (academic)|Barry Smith]] as her supervisor. She was a postdoctoral fellow at the Centre for Consciousness and the Philosophy Program directed by [[David Chalmers]] at [[Australian National University]] from 2007 to 2009,{{cite web|url=http://consciousness.anu.edu.au/people|title=People|publisher=}} and her first tenure-track position was at [[Southern Illinois University Edwardsville|Southern Illinois University, Edwardsville]], from 2001 to 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.ratemyprofessors.com/ShowRatings.jsp?tid=624797|title=Berit Brogaard at Southern Illinois University - Edwardsville - RateMyProfessors.com|publisher=}} She was subsequently appointed Associate Professor of Philosophy (2008–2012) and Professor of Philosophy (2012–2014) at University of Missouri, St. Louis. She has taught at the [[University of Miami]] since 2014. She has been President of the Southern Society for Philosophy and Psychology and was the first female President of the Central States Philosophical Association.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.umsl.edu/news/2013/04/01/society-fellowship/|title=1 scholar to lead philosophy, psychology society; another nabs Princeton fellowship - UMSL Daily|author=|work=UMSL Daily}}[http://www.cspaonline.com Central States Philosophical Association] Brogaard is also a Danish-language poet.''International Who's Who in Poetry'' 2005 Europa Publications, - Page 218 "BROGAARD-PEDERSEN,. Berit. Oskar. ; PhD Researcher, Writer and Poet; b. 28 Aug. 1970, Copenhagen, Denmark. ... Publications: Danskere til Salg, 1991; Livet I lysthuset, 1992; Solnedgangens Orange Born, 1994; Handen der fandt ud af ..." She is co-editor of the [[Philosophical Gourmet Report]], a ranking of philosophy graduate programs, since 2014. Since 2009 Brogaard has worked as a freelance writer for many popular media outlets, including Psychology Today,{{cite web|url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-superhuman-mind|title=The Superhuman Mind|work=Psychology Today}} [[Hello Magazine]] and the [[Lance Armstrong Foundation]]. Since then she has written about 300 popular articles on brain intervention and emotional regulation.{{cite web|url=http://sites.google.com/site/brogaardmainstream/|title=Mainstream|publisher=}} She has also co-authored a breakup program with counselor and relationship expert Catherine Behan entitled The Breakup Cleanse.{{cite web|url=http://breakupcleansebook.com/|title=The Breakup Cleanse|work=The Breakup Cleanse}} Brogaard's research regarding relationships has been featured in publications like Cosmo where she addresses physiological components to having people one is romantically interested in not responding, or responding apathetically to their text messages.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cosmo.ph/relationships/signs-dating-afraid-commitment-src-intl-a1552-20171004-lfrm|title=16 Signs You're Dating Someone Who's Afraid Of Commitment|work=cosmo.ph|access-date=2018-02-03|language=en}} Additionally, she has written about other contemporary social dynamics such as how to handle the consequences of work-place gossip, using reverse psychology to handle undesirable work environments, and common emotional warning signs between relationship partners.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.nl/how-to-deal-with-gossip-at-work-2017-3/|title=4 ways to deal with a coworker who's spreading gossip about you|date=2017-03-22|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-02-03|language=en-US}} Her academic and popular work has been featured in, among other places, A Report of the President's council on [[bioethics]] - Washington D.C. 2004,{{cite web|url=http://bioethics.georgetown.edu/pcbe/reports/stemcell/chapter3.html|title=PCBE: Monitoring Stem Cell Research: Chapter 3: Recent Developments in the Ethical and Policy Debates|publisher=}} Danish National Radio,{{cite web|url=http://www.dr.dk/P1/Videnskabensverden/Udsendelser/2011/05/09103811_1_1.htm|title=Videnskabens Verden|work=Videnskabens Verden - dr.dk}} the Modesto Bee,[http://www.modbee.com/2010/05/30/1187677/workwise-good-luck-bad-luck-and.html the Modesto Bee] UMSL newsroom,{{cite web|url=http://blogs.umsl.edu/news/2010/06/22/brit/Researcher|title=Researcher pens book on history of air travel|author=|work=UMSL Daily}}{{cite web|url=http://blogs.umsl.edu/news/?attachment_id=24394|title=brogaard_brit_400|author=|work=UMSL Daily}}{{cite web|url=http://blogs.umsl.edu/news/2013/01/30/colors-letters/|title=Seeing letters as colors: UMSL professor studies synesthesia|author=|work=UMSL Daily}} MostMost,{{cite web|url=http://www.mostmost.net/2010/07/08/10-relationship-rules-you-should-break/|title=10 Relationship Rules You Should Break - MostMost News|publisher=}} Attract Your Soul Mate Now,{{cite web|url=http://www.blogtalkradio.com/attractyoursoulmatenow/2010/06/30/true-love-chemistry-echoes-neuroscience-and-happily-ever-after|title=True Love Chemistry Echoes Neuroscience and Happily Ever After|date=30 June 2010|work=BlogTalkRadio}} Nightline,{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/health/2012/04/27/real-beautiful-mind-accidental-genius-draws-complex-math-formulas-photos/ |title=Real ‘Beautiful Mind’: College Dropout Became Mathematical Genius After Mugging (PHOTOS) |deadurl=no |accessdate=17 March 2013}} NPR,{{cite web|url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/seeing-sounds-hearing-colors-st-louis-synesthesia-lab-explores-rare-condition|title=Seeing Sounds, Hearing Colors: UMSL Professor Researches Rare Condition|author1=Alex Heuer |author2=Mary Edwards |author3=Don Marsh |publisher=}} Popular Science,{{cite web |url=http://www.popsci.com/science/article/2013-02/when-brain-damage-unlocks-genius-within |title=When Brain Damage Unlocks The Genius Within |deadurl=no |accessdate=17 March 2013}} Science Omega,{{cite web |url=http://www.scienceomega.com/article/678/synaesthesia-and-savant-syndrome-are-we-all-superhuman |title=Synaesthesia and savant syndrome: are we all superhuman? |deadurl=no |accessdate=17 March 2013}} the Huffington Post,{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/30/college-dropout-jason-pad_n_1464835.html |title=College Dropout Jason Padgett Becomes Accidental Mathematical Genius After Brutal Mugging |deadurl=no |accessdate=17 March 2013 |work=Huffington Post |first=Dominique |last=Mosbergen |date=30 April 2012}} and ABC News. == Philosophical work == === Cognitive neuroscience === In the area of [[cognitive neuroscience]] Brogaard is best known for her work on [[synesthesia]] and [[savant syndrome]].{{cite news|title=Case Study of Accidental Genius|newspaper=Danish National Public Radio}}{{cite news|title=Man Becomes Genius After Head Injury|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/video/man-genius-head-injury-16233262?tab=9482930§ion=1206872&playlist=1887643|newspaper=ABC Nightline|date=2012-04-27}}{{cite news|last=Karlinsky|first=Neal|title=Real ‘Beautiful Mind’: College Dropout Became Mathematical Genius After Mugging|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/health/2012/04/27/real-beautiful-mind-accidental-genius-draws-complex-math-formulas-photos/|newspaper=ABC News|date=2012-04-27}}{{cite news|title=College Dropout Jason Padgett Becomes Accidental Mathematical Genius After Brutal Mugging|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/30/college-dropout-jason-pad_n_1464835.html|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=2012-04-30|first=Dominique|last=Mosbergen}}{{cite news|last=Edgington|first=Katy|title=Synaesthesia and savant syndrome: are we all superhuman?|url=http://www.scienceomega.com/article/678/synaesthesia-and-savant-syndrome-are-we-all-superhuman|newspaper=Science Omega|date=2 November 2012}}{{cite news|last=Marsh|first=Don|title=Seeing Sounds, Hearing Colors: UMSL Professor Researches Rare Condition|url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/seeing-sounds-hearing-colors-umsl-professor-researches-rare-condition|newspaper=NPR|date=4 February 2013}}{{cite news|last=Piore|first=Adam|title=When Brain Damage Unlocks The Genius Within|url=http://www.popsci.com/science/article/2013-02/when-brain-damage-unlocks-genius-within|newspaper=Popular Science|date=2013-02-19}}[http://xa.yimg.com/kq/groups/18473864/846497944/name/Fractals+and+the+Mind.pdf Fractals and the Mind, Explorations September 2012] Her team, which consists of colleagues from the Brogaard Lab for Multisensory Research,{{cite web|url=http://www.brogaardlab.com|title=Brogaard Lab for Multisensory Research - Synesthesia - Savant Syndrome - Autism|work=Brogaard Lab for Multisensory Research}} and the Visual Awareness and Cognition Group, Brain Research Unit, Low Temperature Laboratory, Aalto University School of Science, Finland{{cite web|url=http://ltl.tkk.fi/wiki/BRU/Vision_Systems_Neuroscience|title=Vision Systems Neuroscience|publisher=}} just completed a series of studies on Jason Padgett,{{cite web | url= http://www.struckbygenius.com/ | title= Struck By Genius}} who has acquired savant syndrome and acquired synesthesia. Jason Padgett was mugged in 2002.{{cite web | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/brain-injury-created-mathematical-genius-2014-5?nr_email_referer=1 | title=A Brain Injury Turned A Regular Guy Into A Mathematical Genius | publisher=Business Insider | date=6 May 2014 | accessdate=7 May 2014 | author=Lewis, Tanya}} He was hit on his head and developed a form of synesthesia and savant syndrome. Certain objects and mathematical formulas trigger synesthetic mathematical fractals in him. He is the first to hand-draw mathematical fractals, an ability he acquired after the incident.{{cite web|url=http://fineartamerica.com/profiles/jason-padgett.html|title=Jason Padgett|work=Fine Art America}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fantastic-fractals.com/Make-a-Fractal.html|title=How to Make a Fractal|publisher=}} In a series of functional [[Magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]] studies in [[Finland]], Brogaard's team found uni-lateral left-side activity in the parietal and frontal areas when Padgett is exposed to well-formed mathematical formulas that give rise to synesthetic fractals in him and bi-lateral activation when he is exposed to nonsense formulas or formulas that don't give rise to synesthetic fractals. They re-tested the results from the [[Functional magnetic resonance imaging|Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI)]] using [[Transcranial magnetic stimulation|Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS)]]. In the TMS study, Padgett was shown formulas and asked to rate his synesthetic sensation on a scale 1-10, relative to his "baseline" percept (i.e. without TMS). They applied TMS over the brain areas that were activated in the fMRI scan with the formulas that give rise to synesthetic experiences and found the TMS modulated two central areas. The results establish for the first time that synesthetic imagery may be generated in areas of the brain not normally used for the creation of visual imagery.{{cite web|url=http://cercor.oxfordjournals.org/content/14/12/1376.abstract|title=Mental Visual Synthesis is Originated in the Fronto-temporal Network of the Left Hemisphere|author=Yukihito Yomogida|publisher=}} Jason Padgett has since then published an autobiography with Maureen Seaberg.{{cite web|url=http://www.struckbygenius.com|title=Struck by Genius|publisher=}} The book is being turned into a major Hollywood movie, starring Channing Tatum.{{cite web | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/channing-tatum-tackling-struck-by-732971 | title= Channing Tatum Tackling 'Struck by Genius' Adaptation (Exclusive) |publisher= The Hollywood Reporter | date= 2014-09-17 | accessdate= Feb 7, 2015 | author= Boris Kit}} Brogaard's lab has also studied the cognitive mechanisms underlying grapheme-color synesthesia, one of the most common forms of synesthesia.{{cite book|title=The LTP Model for Grapheme-Color Binding in Synesthesia. In: Sensory Integration and the Unity of Consciousness|year=2013|publisher=MIT Press|editor1=Bennet D |editor2=Hill C }} Using a novel visual search paradigm to examine whether synesthetic colors guide the subject’s attention to the location of the target they found that synesthetic experience requires selective attention to occur. In light of this they propose a new long term potentiation model for grapheme-color projector synesthesia. Brogaard has also contributed to the topic of whether there are unconscious perceptual processes, arguing that cases of blindsight and visual for action involve unconscious perceptual processes.{{cite journal|last=Overgaard|first=Morten|author2=Grünbaum, Thor|title=Consciousness and modality: On the possible preserved visual consciousness in blindsight subjects|journal=Consciousness and Cognition|date=1 December 2011|volume=20|issue=4|pages=1855–1859|doi=10.1016/j.concog.2011.08.016}}{{cite journal|last=Brogaard|first=Berit|title=Non-visual consciousness and visual images in blindsight|journal=Consciousness and Cognition|date=9 Jan 2012|volume=21|issue=1|pages=595–596|doi=10.1016/j.concog.2011.12.003}} === Philosophy of mind === In the area of philosophy of mind, Brogaard is the first to provide a thorough analysis of perceptual words such as 'look', 'sound', 'feel', 'taste', 'smell', 'seem', 'appear', 'see' and 'hear'.{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&pid=explorer&chrome=true&srcid=0B0GEjtSycjTKZGM2MjkxZmQtMmMxOS00Y2ZiLWIxM2YtOWZjOGE5YTM5YzEy&hl=en_US|title=PerceptualReports.pdf|work=Google Docs}} She argues that perceptual reports containing these words reflect the content of perception.{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/de/itunes-u/center-for-mathematical-philosophy/id439913748?ls=1|title=„MCMP – Mathematical Philosophy (Archive 2011/12)“ - Kostenloser Podcast von Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München in iTunes|work=iTunes}}{{cite book|last=Deroy|first=Ophelia|title=Synesthesia: An experience of the third kind?. In: Consciousness Inside and Out: Phenomenology, Neuroscience, and the Nature of Experience.|year=2013|publisher=Springer|editor=Brown R}} Brogaard is also the first researcher to show that consciousness comes in degrees and that there can be borderline cases of consciousness.{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/fileview?id=0B0GEjtSycjTKZGY2NDUwNmItYzkzNi00ODA1LTkxOGEtNzU5OWEyZjQyYjY4&hl=en&authkey=CJuan98N|title=Is Conscious a Gradable Adjective.pdf|work=Google Docs}} Imagine a case where we slowly destroy the primary visual cortex of a subject, one neuron at a time in an arbitrary fashion. Plausibly such an individual would proceed slowly from perceiving her surroundings normally to perceiving them unconsciously. In this process, the brightness of the perceived content would gradually decrease until a point at which it would be unclear whether the perception counted as weakly conscious. Or consider [[George Sperling]]'s classic experiment in which a 3 x 3 array of letters was briefly flashed to the test subjects. Most subjects said that they were aware of all the letters, even though they could report only about half of them. To test whether the subjects were right, Sperling used a tone after the presentation of the stimulus to signal which row the subjects should report (high tone = top row, medium tone = middle row and low tone = the bottom row). The subjects were able to name the letters in the indicated row but they were unable to report any other numbers. The fact that the subjects were able to report any signaled row indicates that they were phenomenally conscious of all the rows but did not have access consciousness to all of them. But suppose we were to flash a 4 x 4 array of letters, then a 5 x 5 array of letters, then 6 x 6 array of letters, and so on, to subjects in an experiment. In that case, it would naturally become harder and harder for them to report the rows as the array became increasingly more complicated. There would, however, be no precise cut-off at which the subjects would go from being weakly conscious to not being weakly conscious of all the rows. === Philosophy of language === Brogaard is also a well known contributor to the philosophy of language. Brogaard's book, Transient Truths provides the first book-length exposition and defense of temporalism,{{cite web|url=http://ndpr.nd.edu/news/36173-transient-truths-an-essay-in-the-metaphysics-of-propositions/|title=Transient Truths: An Essay in the Metaphysics of Propositions|author=ENR // AgencyND // University of Notre Dame|publisher=}}{{cite web|last=Pacific Division of the APA|title=Author-Meets-Critics: Brit Brogaard, Transient Truths: An Essay in the Metaphysics of Propositions|url=http://apa-pacific.org/current/main-program.php|year=2013}} the view that contents can change their truth-values along with changes in the world. Brogaard argues that temporal contents are contents and propositions in the full sense. This project involves a thorough analysis of how we talk about and retain mental states over time, an examination of how the phenomenology of mental states bear on the content of mental states, an analysis of how we pass on information in temporally extended conversations, and a revival of a Priorian tense logic. The view suggests a broader view according to which some types of representation have a determinate truth-value only relative to features about the subject who does the representing. If this view is right, successful semantic representation requires an eye on our own position in the world. Brogaard has also offered well known philosophical accounts of moral permissibility,{{cite journal|last=Brogaard|first=Berit|title=MORAL CONTEXTUALISM AND MORAL RELATIVISM|journal=The Philosophical Quarterly|date=1 July 2008|volume=58|issue=232|pages=385–409|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9213.2007.543.x}}{{cite journal|last=Binderup|first=Lars|title=BROGAARD'S MORAL CONTEXTUALISM|journal=The Philosophical Quarterly|date=1 July 2008|volume=58|issue=232|pages=410–415|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9213.2007.544.x}}{{cite journal|last=Damschen|first=G|author2=Gómez-Lobo, A |author3=Schönecker, D |title=Sixteen days? A reply to B. Smith and B. Brogaard on the beginning of human individuals.|journal=The Journal of medicine and philosophy|date=April 2006|volume=31|issue=2|pages=165–75|pmid=16595346|doi=10.1080/03605310600588707}}{{cite journal|last=Björnsson|first=Gunnar|author2=Finlay, Stephen|title=Metaethical Contextualism Defended*|journal=Ethics|date=1 October 2010|volume=121|issue=1|pages=7–36|doi=10.1086/656304}}{{cite journal|last=Francén|first=Ragnar|title=No deep disagreement for new relativists|journal=Philosophical Studies|volume=151|issue=1|pages=19–37|doi=10.1007/s11098-009-9414-6}}{{cite journal|last=Jenkins|first=C.S.|author2=Nolan, Daniel|title=Maximising, Satisficing and Context*|journal=Noûs|date=1 September 2010|volume=44|issue=3|pages=451–468|doi=10.1111/j.1468-0068.2010.00750.x}}{{cite journal|last=Baker|first=Carl|title=Indexical contextualism and the challenges from disagreement|journal=Philosophical Studies|volume=157|issue=1|pages=107–123|doi=10.1007/s11098-010-9621-1}} anti-realism,{{cite journal|last=Moretti|first=Luca|title=Brogaard and Salerno on antirealism and the conditional fallacy|journal=Philosophical Studies|volume=140|issue=2|pages=229–246|doi=10.1007/s11098-007-9139-3}}{{cite journal|last=Rosenkranz|first=S.|title=Fitch back in action again?|journal=Analysis|date=1 January 2004|volume=64|issue=1|pages=67–71|doi=10.1093/analys/64.1.67}}{{cite journal|last=Rosenkranz|first=Sven|title=Knowability, Closure, and Anti-Realism|journal=Dialectica|date=1 March 2008|volume=62|issue=1|pages=59–75|doi=10.1111/j.1746-8361.2007.01129.x}} and knowledge-how.{{cite journal|last=SCHAFFER|first=JONATHAN|title=Knowing the Answer Redux: Replies to Brogaard and Kallestrup|journal=Philosophy and Phenomenological Research|date=1 March 2009|volume=78|issue=2|pages=477–500|doi=10.1111/j.1933-1592.2009.00252.x}} Brogaard is furthermore the first to develop a dynamic two-dimensional semantics that can account for cognitive significance in a dynamic setting.{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/fileview?id=0B0GEjtSycjTKMTEwMTkyZmUtZjZiZi00MDU5LThmYTQtZDJlNThlOWFkNzI0&hl=en|title=Context and Content.pdf|work=Google Docs}} == Books == === ''Transient Truths: An Essay in the Metaphysics of Propositions'' === Transient Truths provides the first book-length exposition and defense temporalism, the philosophical theory that the contents of propositions can change their truth-values along with changes in the world. Brogaard argues that temporal contents are contents and propositions in the full sense. The project involves an analysis of how we talk about and retain mental states over time, an examination of how the phenomenology of mental states bear on the content of mental states, an analysis of how we pass on information in temporally extended conversations, and a revival of a Priorian tense logic. Her view suggests a broader view according to which some types of representation have a determinate truth-value only relative to features about the subject who does the representing. If this view is right, successful semantic representation requires an eye on our own position in the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Transient-Truths-Essay-Metaphysics-Propositions/dp/0199796904/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1440717793&sr=8-1&keywords=transient+truths|title=Amazon.com: Transient Truths: An Essay in the Metaphysics of Propositions (9780199796908): Berit Brogaard: Books|publisher=}} === ''On Romantic Love: Simple Truths About a Complex Emotion'' === Brogaard argues that love is an emotion; that it can be, at turns, both rational and irrational; and that it can be manifested in degrees. We can love one person more than another and we can love a person a little or a lot or not at all and love is not always something we consciously feel. However, love—like other emotions, both conscious and unconscious—is subject to rational control, and falling in or out of it can be a deliberate choice.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Romantic-Love-Complex-Emotion-Philosophy/dp/0199370737/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1440718229&sr=8-1&keywords=on+romantic+love|title=On Romantic Love: Simple Truths about a Complex Emotion (Philosophy in Action): Berit Brogaard: 9780199370733: Amazon.com: Books|publisher=}} === ''The Superhuman Mind: Free the Genius in Your Brain'' === Brogaard and co-author Kristian Marlow argue that our brains constantly process a huge amount of information below our awareness, and what individuals with [[savant syndrome]] have in common is that through practice, injury, an innate brain disorder, or even more unusual circumstances, they have managed to gain a degree of conscious access to the brain's innate potent processing power. Delving into the neurological underpinnings of savant syndrome, the authors reveal how we can acquire some of these skills ourselves—from perfect pitch and lightning fast math skills to supercharged creativity.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Superhuman-Mind-Free-Genius-Brain/dp/1594633681/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1440718358&sr=8-1&keywords=the+superhuman+mind|title=The Superhuman Mind: Free the Genius in Your Brain: Berit Brogaard PhD PhD, Kristian Marlow MA MA: 9781594633683: Amazon.com: Books|publisher=}} == Bibliography == A partial list of publications by Brogaard: * ''[https://www.amazon.com/Superhuman-Mind-Free-Genius-Brain/dp/1594633681/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1423765334&sr=8-1&keywords=superhuman+mind The Superhuman Mind: Free the Genius in Your Brain]'', Hudson Street Press, 2015 * ''[https://www.amazon.com/Romantic-Love-Complex-Emotion-Philosophy/dp/0199370737/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1423765529&sr=8-1&keywords=on+romantic+love On Romantic Love: Simple Truths about a Complex Emotion]'', Oxford University Press, 2015 * ''[https://www.amazon.com/Transient-Truths-Essay-Metaphysics-Propositions/dp/0199796904/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1423765608&sr=8-1&keywords=transient+truths Transient Truths: An Essay in the Metaphysics of Propositions]'', Oxford University Press, 2012 * ''[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&pid=explorer&chrome=true&srcid=0B0GEjtSycjTKZGFlMjRjMDItNzRkYi00MDI2LTlmYzUtNWEzY2NkNzEyNDU5&hl=en Vision for Action and the Contents of Perception]'', ''Journal of Philosophy'', 2011 * ''[http://sites.google.com/site/brogaardb/FeelsReportsII.pdf?attredirects=0 What do We Say When We Say How or What We Feel?]'', ''Philosophers Imprint'', 2011 * ''[https://docs.google.com/fileview?id=0B0GEjtSycjTKNTJhMjMyNmEtM2NmMy00OTJhLTk4MjMtYjRhYzE4NGRkNGY1&hl=en Are There Unconscious Perceptual Processes?]'', ''Consciousness and Cognition'', 2010, {{doi|10.1016/j.concog.2010.10.002}}, in press * ''[https://docs.google.com/fileview?id=0B0GEjtSycjTKZTA2NGQ1MzgtZTZhNS00MWMyLTk0YzYtY2I1OWVjMTE2ZWU1&hl=en Conscious Vision for Action Vs. Unconscious Vision for Action]'', ''Cognitive Science'', in press * ''[https://docs.google.com/fileview?id=0B0GEjtSycjTKN2Y3NjE2ZmUtNThiOS00YzY1LThjMmUtOGU2NDQzMDA0Mzg4&hl=en Color Experience in Blindsight?]'' ''Philosophical Psychology'', in press * ''[https://docs.google.com/fileview?id=0B0GEjtSycjTKODgyMGZhOTUtZDNjMC00M2FjLWE1OWQtMTYwM2FhNjlhMzI3&hl=en Stupid People Deserve What They Get': The Effects of Personality Assessment on Judgments of Intentional Action]'', ''Behavioral and Brain Sciences 33'', 2010, 332-334 * ''[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&pid=explorer&chrome=true&srcid=0B0GEjtSycjTKZGM2MjkxZmQtMmMxOS00Y2ZiLWIxM2YtOWZjOGE5YTM5YzEy&hl=en_US Perceptual Reports]'', forthcoming in Mohan Matthen, ed. ''Oxford Handbook of the Philosophy of Perception'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2010 * ''[http://sites.google.com/site/brogaardb/CommentsonUriahKriegel.pdf?attredirects=0 Are Conscious States Conscious in Virtue of Representing Themselves?]'', forthcoming in Philosophical Studies * ''[http://sites.google.com/site/brogaardb/ColorContentandMonadicTruth.pdf?attredirects=0 Perceptual Content and Monadic Truth: On Cappelen and Hawthorne's Relativism and Monadic Truth]'', forthcoming in David Sosa, ed. ''Philosophical Books'' * ''[http://www.springerlink.com/content/np47572813w2x557/ Strong Representationalism and Centered Content]'', ''Philosophical Studies 151'', 2010, 373–392. {{doi|10.1007/s11098-009-9437-z}} * ''[https://docs.google.com/fileview?id=0B0GEjtSycjTKMTEwMTkyZmUtZjZiZi00MDU5LThmYTQtZDJlNThlOWFkNzI0&hl=en Context and Content: Pragmatics in Two-Dimensional Semantics]'', Keith Allan and Kasia Jaszczolt, eds. ''Cambridge Handbook of Pragmatics'', 2010 == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://sites.google.com/site/brogaardb/}} * [http://brogaardlab.com Brogaard Lab for Multisensory Perception] * [http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-superhuman-mind The Superhuman Mind: True Tales of Extraordinary Mental Ability] * [http://sites.google.com/site/brogaardb/cv Berit Brogaard’s curriculum vitae] * [http://lemmingsblog.blogspot.com/ Lemmings – Brogaard's academic blog] * [http://www.lovesicklove.com/ Lovesick Love – Brogaard's popular blog] * [http://blog.hellomagazine.com/theres-something-mary/ There is something about Mary: Princess Diaries – Hello Magazine] * [http://www.blogtalkradio.com/attractyoursoulmatenow/2010/06/30/true-love-chemistry-echoes-neuroscience-and-happily-ever-after Interview with Brogaard by relation expert Catherine Behan] * [http://www.whohub.com/beritbrogaard Interview with Brogaard in WhoHub] * [http://www.whatisitliketobeaphilosopher.com/#/beritbogaard/ Autobiographical interview with Brogaard at What Is It Like to Be a Philosopher?] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brogaard, Berit Oskar}} [[Category:20th-century American philosophers]] [[Category:21st-century American philosophers]] [[Category:Analytic philosophers]] [[Category:American academics]] [[Category:Australian National University faculty]] [[Category:Consciousness researchers and theorists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Philosophers of mind]] [[Category:Cognitive neuroscientists]] [[Category:1970 births]] [[Category:University of Missouri–St. Louis people]] [[Category:Philosophers of language]] [[Category:University of Copenhagen alumni]]
